question_sentence: President Joe Biden welcomed which world leader to the White House for a state dinner this week?
evidence: Biden hosted Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi at the White House on Thursday for a lavish, tented state dinner that featured a plant-based menu for the guest of honor, who is a vegetarian.

question_sentence: Secretary of State Antony Blinken traveled to which country this week in an effort to “stabilize” relations?
evidence: Blinken traveled to China for meetings with top officials, including President Xi Jinping. Blinken is the first US secretary of state to visit Beijing in five years, and his talks were seen as a key litmus test for whether the two governments can stop relations from continuing to deteriorate at a time of lingering distrust.

question_sentence: Which public figure will plead guilty to federal tax charges?
evidence: Hunter Biden, the son of President Joe Biden, will plead guilty to two tax misdemeanors and struck a deal with federal prosecutors to resolve a felony gun charge, the Justice Department said Tuesday in court filings. As part of the plea agreement, the DOJ has agreed to recommend a sentence of probation for the two counts of failing to pay taxes in a timely matter for the years 2017 and 2018, according to sources.

question_sentence: The United Nations commemorated World Refugee Day on Tuesday. According to UN estimates, approximately how many refugees are there worldwide?
evidence: The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees estimates the number of refugees worldwide is approaching 35 million people — although that number does not include the millions of forcibly displaced people who have not been granted refugee status.

question_sentence: Hackers threatened to leak stolen data from which tech company unless it pays a $4.5 million ransom and changes its controversial pricing policy?
evidence: Hackers from a ransomware gang are threatening to leak 80 gigabytes of confidential data from Reddit that they claim to have stolen during a February breach, according to a post from the group on the dark web, which was reviewed by CNN and an independent cybersecurity expert.

question_sentence: Months after Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas came under scrutiny for accepting lavish trips paid for by a billionaire Republican donor, another justice is in the spotlight for similar reasons. Which justice is it?
evidence: Concerns about ethics and transparency at the Supreme Court have been reignited this week after Justice Samuel Alito acknowledged attending a luxury fishing trip on the private jet of a conservative hedge fund manager.

question_sentence: Netflix recently released a trailer for the second season of which hit show?
evidence: Netflix has shared exclusive new details for the second season of its runaway hit “Squid Game,” the South Korean thriller series in which contestants who are deeply in debt play children’s games in order to win a ton of cash — with the losers getting killed.

question_sentence: Which state is now home to America’s highest gas prices, taking the crown from California?
evidence: The average cost of regular gasoline in Washington has jumped by more than 30 cents in the past month to more than $4.90 a gallon, according to AAA. Gas in California is nearly 10 cents cheaper.

question_sentence: The Federal Trade Commission announced this week it is suing which company, alleging it tricked millions of consumers into signing up for its paid subscription service?
evidence: The FTC is suing Amazon, alleging that the e-commerce giant has tricked millions of consumers into signing up for its Prime subscription service through deceptive user interface designs. The complaint also takes aim at Amazon for allegedly trying to keep users subscribed who wished to cancel their memberships.

question_sentence: Parts of Florida’s Broward County are under quarantine after sightings of which invasive species?
evidence: Some neighborhoods in Broward County are under quarantine after sightings of invasive giant African land snails, which eat at least 500 different types of plants and can also chomp through stucco, plastic recycling bins and even signs.

question_sentence: A Californian man set a new world record by solving a Rubik’s Cube in what time?
evidence: Max Park set the new record for the fastest 3x3x3 Rubik’s Cube time at a competition in Long Beach in his native California. The 21-year-old, who was diagnosed with moderate to severe autism as a child, beat the 3.47-second record set by China’s Yusheng Du in 2018.

question_sentence: Short daily naps may help keep the brain healthy by doing what, according to a newly published University College London study?
choices: Improving blood flow to the hippocampus
evidence: The analysis of data on people aged 40 to 69 linked habitual naps with larger brain volume equivalent to up to 6.5 fewer years of ageing. Find out more with The Week Unwrapped podcast.

question_sentence: Marks & Spencer, WHSmith and Argos are among 202 companies fined a total of around £7 million for failing to do what?
evidence: The firms were also ordered to repay a total of around £5 million in lost wages to 63,000 staff, following investigations by HMRC dating back to 2017. M&S, WHSmith and Argos all said the breaches were unintentional and had been swiftly remedied.

question_sentence: A top chef banned which diners from his Australian restaurant “for mental health reasons”?
evidence: Former “Great British Menu” star John Mountain, originally from Lancashire, posted a message on social media telling vegans to “f*** off”, after getting a negative review from a non-meat eater. On the Facebook page of his Perth restaurant, Fyre, he added that “all vegans are now banned”.

question_sentence: Which singer is being blamed for higher than expected inflation in Sweden?
evidence: The start of the singer’s world tour in Stockholm last month triggered a spike in demand at hotels and restaurants that has now been linked to higher-than-expected inflation of 9.7% in May. For more odd and unexpected news, sign up to the Tall Tales newsletter.

question_sentence: Australia beat England by two wickets in a thrilling first Test of the men’s Ashes series that was played where?
evidence: Australia gained revenge for their agonising two-run Ashes defeat at the Birmingham ground in 2005 on Tuesday, when their fast-bowler captain Pat Cummins led his side to improbable victory with an unbeaten 44.

question_sentence: What percentage of UK adults believe that refugees make a “positive contribution” to society, according to an Ipsos survey?
evidence: The survey of 22,000 adults in 29 countries found that Brits had the third most positive attitude to refugees, after Spain and New Zealand. The global average of adults who believe refugees make a “positive contribution” was 45%.

question_sentence: The Church of England is selling off what kind of shares to “protect God’s creation”?
evidence: The Church of England is selling its investments in BP, Shell and other oil and gas giants because they do not “protect God’s creation”. Archbishop of Canterbury Justin Welby, a former oil industry worker, said the climate crisis “threatens the planet we live on”. For 10 things you need to know each day, sign up to the Daily Briefing newsletter.

question_sentence: Prince William is launching a five-year project to tackle what social crisis?
evidence: Speaking to The Sunday Times, the Prince of Wales pledged to use the Royal Foundation to “end homelessness” in the UK, adding: “I’ve been waiting for the right time to do this.” Prince William was 11 when his mother took him to a homeless shelter in London – “a formative moment” for the young royal, said the paper.

question_sentence: The UK government has given a contract to a travel firm from which country for its planned asylum-seeker housing barges?
evidence: News broke this week that the government handed a £1.6 billion contract to  Australian firm Corporate Travel Management to cover three offshore asylum-seeker vessels. The government claimed the “floatels” would be “significantly cheaper” than housing arrivals in hotels.
